It flips the common script from “tell them what to fix” to “ask them what they want and support them.” For any leader or coach, this book is a powerful reminder that **compassion and inspiration are more effective than pressure and fear** in driving change. By using these principles, one can become an influencer who not only achieves outcomes but also enriches relationships and lives in the process – truly helping people change in a way that lasts.

**Appendix B: Comprehensive Review – Elaboration Likelihood Model (ELM) of Persuasion**

The **Elaboration Likelihood Model (ELM)** is a foundational theory in persuasion science developed by Richard Petty and John Cacioppo in the 1980s[\[25\]](https://www.simplypsychology.org/elaboration-likelihood-model.html#:~:text=,elaboration%20are%20more%20apt%20to)[\[72\]](https://www.simplypsychology.org/elaboration-likelihood-model.html#:~:text=The%20elaboration%20likelihood%20model%20was,consistency%20between%20attitudes%20and%20behaviors). It provides a framework for understanding *how* people process persuasive messages and *why* some attempts lead to lasting attitude change while others yield only temporary or no change. As the name suggests, the key concept is “elaboration” – the amount of thought or cognitive effort someone puts into evaluating a message.

**Dual Routes to Persuasion:** ELM proposes **two routes** by which persuasion can occur[\[73\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=process%20theory%20%20describing%20the,route%20and%20the%20peripheral%20route)[\[74\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=Richard%20E,route%20and%20the%20peripheral%20route): 1\. **Central Route** – This is the **high-elaboration route**. When someone is motivated and able to think carefully about a message, they will scrutinize the content deeply (elaborate on the arguments). Persuasion via this route comes from the *quality of the arguments* and evidence. For example, if you’re very interested in buying a new computer (high motivation) and you understand the technical details (ability), you’ll read spec sheets and expert reviews carefully (central processing). If the arguments convince you – say, that Computer A has significantly better performance per price than B – you’ll form a favorable attitude towards A. According to ELM, attitudes changed through the central route are **stronger**: more durable over time and more predictive of behavior[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=boomerang%20effect%20,their%20processing%20of%20the%20message). This is because the person has internally validated the idea with their own reasoning. In our example, you’d likely be satisfied with your choice and stick with it. 2\. **Peripheral Route** – This is the **low-elaboration route**. When motivation or ability to process is low, people don’t engage deeply; instead, they rely on **peripheral cues** – superficial aspects like the attractiveness of the speaker, the number of arguments (rather than quality), or whether an expert endorses it[\[27\]](https://www.simplypsychology.org/elaboration-likelihood-model.html#:~:text=With%20the%20peripheral%20route%2C%20the,lived%20attitude%20change)[\[75\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=motivated%20to%20centrally%20process%20an,effort%20and). Persuasion via this route is not about logical strength but about *heuristics* (“Experts say it, so it must be true” or “This ad made me feel good, so I like the product”). For instance, if you’re half-watching a TV commercial (low involvement), you might be swayed simply because a celebrity you like is promoting a phone – that positive cue (celebrity) rubs off on your attitude toward the phone, even if you don’t know the specs. Attitudes formed this way tend to be **weaker**: they might change if another shiny cue comes along, and they might not translate into actual behavior (you say you like the phone, but maybe you won’t buy it)[\[27\]](https://www.simplypsychology.org/elaboration-likelihood-model.html#:~:text=With%20the%20peripheral%20route%2C%20the,lived%20attitude%20change)[\[76\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=If%20these%20peripheral%20influences%20go,15).

**Determinants of Route – Motivation and Ability:** ELM outlines key factors that determine which route a person will use in a given situation[\[77\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=The%20two%20most%20influential%20factors,and%20their%20overall%20knowledge): \- **Motivation to Process:** Are they **willing** to think deeply? Personal relevance is a huge driver – if the topic matters to you, motivation is high[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=our%20motivation%20to%20elaborate%2C%20and,changes%20from%20the%20peripheral%20route)[\[79\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=). For example, a proposal about reorganizing your department is highly relevant to you (you’ll process centrally), whereas a proposal about a distant division might not interest you (peripheral cues will dominate). Other motivation factors: does the person enjoy thinking in general (those high in **Need for Cognition** will centrally process more by default)[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=our%20motivation%20to%20elaborate%2C%20and,changes%20from%20the%20peripheral%20route)[\[80\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=either%20supported%20by%20strong%20or,2)? Is there a **need for accuracy** (e.g. an important decision)? Or are they just in a hurry or indifferent? \- **Ability to Process:** Are they **able** to think deeply? This includes knowledge of the subject (if the content is too technical for them, they *can’t* elaborate), and situational factors like distraction, time pressure, or cognitive load[\[81\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=The%20peripheral%20route%20is%20used,interest%20in%20it%2C%20or%20if)[\[77\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=The%20two%20most%20influential%20factors,and%20their%20overall%20knowledge). If someone is tired or multitasking, even if the topic is important, they may default to peripheral processing because ability is constrained. As an example, reading a scientific paper in a noisy café when you’re sleep-deprived – you might rely on the paper’s reputation or author’s credentials (peripheral) rather than fully digesting the methods.

Only when both motivation and ability are sufficiently high will central route processing occur. If either is low, peripheral route likely prevails[\[23\]](https://www.simplypsychology.org/elaboration-likelihood-model.html#:~:text=,personal%20investment%20in%20an%20issue)[\[79\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=). It’s worth noting ELM sees the routes as a continuum rather than a strict either/or – sometimes people use a mix (some elaboration, plus some cue reliance).

**Outcomes of Persuasion via Each Route:** \- **Central Route Outcome:** If persuasion happens, it’s because the person found the arguments compelling after careful thought. The result is an **attitude change that is well-grounded** in cognition. Petty and Cacioppo’s research showed that such attitudes: persist longer (the person remembers the reasoning), resist counter-persuasion better (since they can counter-argue opposing views), and are more likely to guide behavior[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=boomerang%20effect%20,their%20processing%20of%20the%20message). However, central route can also result in *no change* or even negative change if the arguments are not convincing – e.g., strong counter-arguments might lead the person to reject the message entirely or become even more entrenched in their prior attitude (a “boomerang effect” if they perceive the message’s position as disagreeable and weakly supported[\[82\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=personal%20interest%20in%20the%20subject,cues%20present%20in%20the%20situation)). \- **Peripheral Route Outcome:** If persuasion occurs here, it’s often because a **shortcut signal** influenced a decision. For example, a listener might think “The speaker talked smoothly and confidently – sounds legit” or simply “Lots of big words, I guess they know what they’re saying” or “Majority of commenters praise this product, so I’ll go with it.” The attitude change might be just a **temporary compliance** or a susceptibility that could flip soon. ELM notes that if peripheral cues change or fade, the attitude can drift (e.g. a person might be persuaded by an authority figure’s endorsement now, but later another authority or a logical argument could easily change their mind since they didn’t internally process the first message deeply)[\[27\]](https://www.simplypsychology.org/elaboration-likelihood-model.html#:~:text=With%20the%20peripheral%20route%2C%20the,lived%20attitude%20change)[\[76\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=If%20these%20peripheral%20influences%20go,15). It’s also possible with peripheral route that if cues are unnoticed entirely, no change happens (“receiver’s attitude remains unchanged” if the cues don’t register[\[83\]](https://www.simplypsychology.org/elaboration-likelihood-model.html#:~:text=match%20at%20L222%20With%20the,lived%20attitude%20change)). And sometimes peripheral route leads to *fragile change* – the person might agree in the moment but not act on it or hold it firmly. For instance, people might express support for a charity after seeing a moving image (peripheral emotional cue), but unless that is reinforced or converted to central belief (“this charity’s mission aligns with my values”), they may not actually donate or they might forget about it soon.

**Illustrative Example:** To cement understanding, consider an advertisement for a new medication: \- A doctor (authority cue) in a white coat (symbol) explains the drug’s benefits in technical detail for 2 minutes. \- **If the viewer is someone with the condition the drug treats (high relevance) and is paying attention (perhaps they or a family member are looking for treatment),** they will likely use the central route. They’ll think about the claims, maybe weigh the risks/side-effects mentioned, compare it with what they know. If convinced, their attitude toward the drug becomes positive and they might ask their doctor about it – a stable change caused by the content. \- **If the viewer is not personally affected or only half-listening,** peripheral cues dominate. They might just note “It was endorsed by a doctor and had happy background music, sounds good.” If asked immediately after, they might say the drug seems great. But that attitude isn’t based on real understanding; it could evaporate or change if, say, a different commercial with a celebrity promoting a rival drug catches their eye tomorrow.

**Using ELM for Persuasion Strategy:** The ELM is very practical. It teaches that to effectively persuade, you should: \- **Assess your audience’s likely route.** Are they likely to care and pay attention? If yes, invest in strong arguments and evidence – make sure your case is rock solid (because they will scrutinize it). If not, focus on making the message appealing and easily digestible – use attractive visuals, credible endorsers, slogans, etc. For example, marketing to busy consumers often relies on peripheral cues (humor, celebrities, simple taglines) because the assumption is low elaboration. But when marketing to technical experts or executives about a crucial decision, you expect high elaboration, so you provide white papers, detailed ROI calculations, etc. \- **Increase motivation and ability if you want central processing.** If you prefer your audience take the central route (since it yields stronger commitment), try to boost their motivation: make the issue feel personally relevant or important to them at the start. Petty & Cacioppo demonstrated this: in a study, students were more persuaded by strong arguments for a new exam policy when they were told it would affect them (high relevance) than when told it wouldn’t affect them for years (low relevance)[\[84\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=Personal%20relevance%20can%20also%20affect,2). Similarly, reduce barriers to ability: ensure your message is clearly organized, not too jargon-laden (or provide necessary background), and delivered in a venue with minimal distractions. Repeating the message can also help ability (more chances to process)[\[85\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=Some%20psychologists%20lump%20opportunity%20in,knowledge%2C%20fatigue%2C%20social%20pressure%2C%20etc). \- **If audience is likely in peripheral mode, use strong cues strategically.** That means if you can’t make them deeply engaged (or you know many won’t be, like a mass audience), focus on things like source credibility and likability (e.g., have a beloved expert present), social proof (“\#1 recommended by physicians” badge), or even sheer volume of points (“50 reasons to choose us” – people might not read all 50, but the number itself is a cue of thoroughness). Note, however, that using too many peripheral cues can backfire if someone does start to scrutinize (they might see it as fluff). So balance accordingly. \- **Aim for central route for enduring change, peripheral for quick impact.** For example, if you’re a manager rolling out a minor procedural update that people aren’t invested in, you might just use a quick peripheral approach (an official memo – authority cue – with a simple rationale and an appeal like “everyone in the company is doing this now”). But if it’s a major cultural shift or strategy change, you need employees to deeply buy in; thus you’d hold interactive sessions to get them engaged in central processing (discussing *why* and *how*, addressing concerns) because you need that lasting internalized commitment.

**ELM and Other Models:** It’s useful to note ELM’s central vs. peripheral routes are conceptually similar to Daniel Kahneman’s **System 2 vs. System 1** (analytical vs. intuitive thinking) or Shelly Chaiken’s **Systematic vs. Heuristic processing** – all distinguish careful thought from shortcut thought in persuasion[\[75\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=motivated%20to%20centrally%20process%20an,effort%20and). The idea that “not all persuasive efforts are processed equally” is widely accepted, and ELM gives a robust scaffolding to predict outcomes.

**Research Example:** A study mentioned in ELM literature showed how **argument quality** and **source credibility** had different effects depending on involvement. With high involvement audiences, *argument quality* (central cue) determined persuasion more – strong arguments led to attitude change, weak arguments led to none or opposite change. Source credibility didn’t matter as much because people thought for themselves[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=boomerang%20effect%20,their%20processing%20of%20the%20message). With low involvement audiences, *source credibility* (peripheral cue) had a larger impact – a message from an expert was accepted even if the arguments were weak (people weren’t scrutinizing), whereas a non-expert giving even strong arguments didn’t sway them because they weren’t listening closely[\[75\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=motivated%20to%20centrally%20process%20an,effort%20and)[\[86\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elaboration_likelihood_model#:~:text=issue%2C%20then%20these%20heuristics%20can,Peripheral%20route). This kind of experiment validates the ELM predictions.

**Limitations and Misconceptions:** The ELM does not say that central is *always* better – if your audience is unlikely to go central, a peripheral win is still a win (you might just have to reinforce it more often). Also, people can shift routes – e.g., repeated exposure might gradually increase interest (someone initially unmotivated becomes curious over time, moving into central processing on later exposures). Additionally, “peripheral” cues can still lead to lasting change if they happen to trigger something deeply meaningful (like an emotional epiphany). But generally, ELM is a guide: for **lasting attitude change**, foster central processing with solid arguments[\[87\]](https://www.simplypsychology.org/elaboration-likelihood-model.html#:~:text=,lasting%20attitude%20change)[\[27\]](https://www.simplypsychology.org/elaboration-likelihood-model.html#:~:text=With%20the%20peripheral%20route%2C%20the,lived%20attitude%20change); for **immediate or low-effort influence**, optimize peripheral cues knowing the change may be transient[\[27\]](https://www.simplypsychology.org/elaboration-likelihood-model.html#:~:text=With%20the%20peripheral%20route%2C%20the,lived%20attitude%20change).

In summary, the Elaboration Likelihood Model is a valuable lens for anyone trying to persuade. It reminds us to tailor our approach to the audience’s likely level of engagement. For scientifically minded executives and engineers, it provides a reassuring structure: **if you want to persuade colleagues or customers, first gauge their motivation/ability, then choose the route**. Use high-quality data and logic for those who will appreciate it, and use psychological cues and simplified messaging for those who won’t delve deeply[\[88\]](https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/article/elaboration-likelihood-model-theory-using-elm-to-get-inside-the-user-s-mind?srsltid=AfmBOopHzl8tFQ9IrrdM_ZHWLzeWRqyc_04ueBs1GC7-W6yFfIeK8yLU#:~:text=Central%20route%20processing%20involves%20a,as%20they%20seek%20their%20goals)[\[89\]](https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/article/elaboration-likelihood-model-theory-using-elm-to-get-inside-the-user-s-mind?srsltid=AfmBOopHzl8tFQ9IrrdM_ZHWLzeWRqyc_04ueBs1GC7-W6yFfIeK8yLU#:~:text=Peripheral%20route%20processing%20involves%20a,the%20specific%20features%20of%20laptops). Or better yet, try to move people into caring enough to use the central route by making the issue salient to them. Ultimately, combining both – a strong core argument plus engaging presentation – is a best practice that ELM supports: *“appeal to users via both central and peripheral processing routes… not risk alienating either one”*[\[30\]](https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/article/elaboration-likelihood-model-theory-using-elm-to-get-inside-the-user-s-mind?srsltid=AfmBOopHzl8tFQ9IrrdM_ZHWLzeWRqyc_04ueBs1GC7-W6yFfIeK8yLU#:~:text=Incorporating%20ELM%20in%20your%20design%3A,accessing%20user%E2%80%99s%20abilities).

**Appendix C: Comprehensive Summary – *Magic Words: What to Say to Get Your Way* (Jonah Berger)**

Jonah Berger’s **Magic Words** (2023) delves into the subtle power of language and how specific types of words can dramatically increase your ability to persuade, motivate, and connect with others[\[90\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=In%20Magic%20Words%3A%20What%20to,our%20perceptions%20and%20decision%20making). Unlike some influence books that focus on broad principles, *Magic Words* zeroes in on the **micro-level of communication**: the phrases, wording choices, and linguistic signals that can change the outcome of an interaction. Berger, a marketing professor and researcher, identifies **six key types of words** (forming the mnemonic **“SPEACC”** framework) that can enhance your impact in every area of life[\[91\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=There%20are%20types%20of%20magic,the%20framework%20he%20calls%20SPEACC)[\[55\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=framework%20he%20calls%20SPEACC%3A). These categories are: **Similarity**, **Questions**, **Emotion**, **Agency/Identity**, **Confidence**, and **Concreteness**[\[55\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=framework%20he%20calls%20SPEACC%3A)[\[56\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=,show%20you%E2%80%99re%20listening%3F%20Be%20concrete). We’ll summarize each “magic word” category, along with examples and techniques from the book:

1. **Language of Similarity (S):** People are influenced by those they feel are **similar to them** or “speak the same language.” This isn’t just metaphorical – Berger discusses how *linguistic mirroring* (using similar vocabulary, jargon, or communication style as the person you’re trying to influence) can build rapport and trust[\[92\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=,build%20better%20presentations%2C%20have%20better)[\[56\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=,show%20you%E2%80%99re%20listening%3F%20Be%20concrete). Research shows that linguistic similarity is correlated with everything from successful negotiations to songs becoming hits[\[92\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=,build%20better%20presentations%2C%20have%20better). Practically, this means paying attention to the words others use and strategically echoing them. For example, if a colleague tends to say “challenge” instead of “problem,” using their term can subtly signal *“I’m like you; I get you.”* Berger cites findings that people who matched a counterpart’s function words (like pronouns, articles) during conversation were more likely to reach agreement – the matching fosters an unconscious bond. In customer interactions, using the same descriptors the customer uses (e.g., “I want something *robust*” – later you say “this robust solution…”) makes them feel understood. However, it must feel natural – forced mirroring can backfire if it seems like mockery. The key is genuinely tune into their language and let it inform yours. Over longer term, adopting the “dialect” of a group (without overdoing it) helps you become an accepted insider, which increases your influence within that group.

2. **Language of Questions (P – Posing Questions):** Asking the right questions is a powerful yet underappreciated way to influence. Berger’s research upends the notion that asking questions might make you seem uninformed; instead, *questions can make you appear more* *competent and thoughtful*[**\[42\]**](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=gets%20promoted%20to%20whether%20songs,who%E2%80%99s%20in%20charge%2C%20who%E2%80%99s%20to)**. The reason is twofold: first, asking questions encourages engagement – it invites others to contribute and signals that you value their perspective, which increases your likability and credibility. Second, certain types of questions guide people to think along certain lines or even persuade themselves. Berger notes that** open-ended questions **(especially “How” and “What” questions) are effective in consultation and sales because they get people to articulate needs that you can then solve. For instance, a salesperson might ask “What’s your biggest pain point in this process?” – as the client answers, they are essentially highlighting problems that the salesperson’s product can address, making them receptive to the solution. Another insight: asking questions can frame the expectations. A subtle example from the book: Instead of saying “I think this project will be challenging but doable,” a leader might ask the team “How can we make sure this challenging project is a success?” – this phrasing acknowledges difficulty but immediately focuses everyone on solution-finding, implying success is achievable (it presupposes a positive outcome). Berger also discusses the power of** rhetorical questions\*\* in presentations – e.g., “Is this the kind of growth we want for our company?” – which can be more persuasive than a statement because it prompts the audience to answer internally and reach the conclusion you intend (in this case likely “No, we want more growth,” paving way for your proposal).

3. **Language of Emotion (E):** Words that convey emotion can make your communication far more compelling. Berger explains that **emotional language** engages people’s attention and memory – we tend to perk up and remember things that make us feel something[\[93\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=It%E2%80%99s%20not%20surprising%20that%20we,the%20message%20and%20the%20messenger)[\[94\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=generally%20prefer%20concrete%20language%20like,the%20message%20and%20the%20messenger). He gives examples like the famous RAID insecticide slogan: “Raid *Kills Bugs Dead*.” This simple phrase is very concrete (more on concreteness later) but also emotionally charged – “kills” and “dead” pack a punch, eliciting a visceral response that *“protects your home from insects”* wouldn’t[\[93\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=It%E2%80%99s%20not%20surprising%20that%20we,the%20message%20and%20the%20messenger). Emotional words can be positive or negative depending on context, but the key is they **generate feeling**. Berger notes that *uncertain emotions* (like surprise, curiosity, suspense) can especially drive engagement[\[95\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=Another%20point%20is%20that%20uncertain,beginning%20has%20kept%20you%20reading). For example, starting a presentation with “Imagine…” or telling a short suspenseful story can hook listeners through emotional intrigue. Another application is in **storytelling** – peppering your narrative with sensory and emotional descriptors (“thrilled,” “frustrating,” “heartwarming”) transports the audience into the story, making them care more about the outcome. Berger advises varying emotional language to keep people interested (“mix up moments” to avoid monotony[\[96\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=to%20ask%20and%20when%20to,be%20perceived%20more%20positively%3F%20Increase)). However, a caution: match the emotion to your goal and audience. If you need to persuade someone to take a risk, words evoking excitement and confidence are better than ones evoking fear or anger (unless you intentionally want to channel outrage for action in some cases). The book also mentions that overly certain emotions like anger can sometimes reduce openness, whereas a bit of uncertainty (like mystery or anticipation) can pull people in[\[95\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=Another%20point%20is%20that%20uncertain,beginning%20has%20kept%20you%20reading). In any case, moving beyond bland, analytical language to include feeling words is a “magic” move for influence – it humanizes you and your message.

4. **Language of Agency and Identity (A):** Perhaps the most intriguing category, this relates to how subtle shifts in phrasing can signal who has agency (control) in a situation and can invoke identity in persuasive ways[\[97\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=conversations%2C%20or%20be%20a%20better,to%20listen%2C%20expressing%20doubt%20can)[\[56\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=,show%20you%E2%80%99re%20listening%3F%20Be%20concrete). **Agency** here means words that indicate who is doing an action and how. For instance, saying *“I* *can’t* *eat sugar”* vs. *“I* *don’t* *eat sugar”*. “Can’t” implies an external restraint (I want to but am not allowed), whereas “don’t” implies personal agency and identity (“I just don’t do that”) – research shows that saying “I don’t X” is more effective for self-control because it affirms your identity and resolve[\[56\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=,show%20you%E2%80%99re%20listening%3F%20Be%20concrete). Berger also points out pronoun use as agency indicators: leaders who say “we” vs. “I” can either include or alienate (strategically use “we” to foster unity, but use “I” when taking responsibility or expressing personal commitment). **Identity language** is a major focus: it’s about turning actions into identities to motivate behavior. Berger recounts studies like the *“be a helper”* study with preschoolers[\[45\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=A%20study%20was%20done%20decades,portion%20of%20students%20that%20helped) and the *“be a voter”* study with adults[\[44\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=explains%20that%20some%20researchers%20tried,Voter%20vs%20Vote). By adding that “-er” or otherwise framing an action as an identity, you invoke people’s self-concept and desire for consistency. It seems minor – “a voter” vs “vote” – but saying “be a voter” led to significantly higher voter turnout[\[44\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=explains%20that%20some%20researchers%20tried,Voter%20vs%20Vote). Why? Because people care about **who they are**, not just what they do. If not voting means “I’m not a voter (and maybe I’m a bad citizen)”, they are more compelled to vote to uphold the identity of “I am a voter, I am a good citizen.” In marketing or leadership, using identity terms can create buy-in: e.g., calling employees “innovators” as a group identity encourages them to live up to that label by being innovative. Berger warns, though, identity language can backfire if used negatively or inappropriately (e.g., labeling someone with a negative identity will just breed resentment)[\[98\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=ideas%20and%20a%20vision%2C%20which,you%20can%E2%80%99t%20get%20this%20to). The book suggests we should harness identity carefully: encourage identities that align with desired actions (like “health-conscious person” rather than “someone on a diet”, or telling your team “You are problem-solvers\!” to get them to tackle a tough issue).

5. **Language of Confidence (C):** The words we choose can signal certainty or hesitancy, and this greatly affects persuasion. Berger notes that people who use **definitive language** (“will”, “definitely”, “the”) are seen as more confident and are more persuasive in many contexts[\[99\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=need%20to%20harness%20the%20language,to%20listen%2C%20expressing%20doubt%20can). Conversely, **hedges** and qualifiers (“maybe”, “I think”, “somewhat”, “in my opinion”) can undermine perceived confidence[\[100\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=,basketball%20player%2C%20I%20recommend%20Jordans)[\[101\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=Which%20statement%20is%20more%20likely,someone%20to%20buy%20the%20Jordans). For example, compare: “In my opinion, this approach could maybe increase efficiency” vs. “This approach will increase efficiency.” The latter is far more convincing due to its certainty, even though the former might feel more polite or cautious to the speaker. Berger’s research found that just switching “I like” to “I recommend” (which removes the personal, subjective hedge and replaces it with a confident suggestion) increased compliance by about 50%[\[41\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=And%20that%E2%80%99s%20where%20we%20get,%E2%80%9D)\! Similarly, speaking in active voice and using present tense can exude confidence – “Our product outperforms the competition” (present, active) instead of “Our product has been seen to outperform...” (more passive, past). However, Berger also acknowledges nuance: sometimes a *little* uncertainty from the speaker can be disarming or invite collaboration. For instance, when trying to get a skeptical audience to open up, admitting a small doubt or asking for advice (“I’m 95% sure, but I’d love your thoughts”) can engage them (this ties back to using questions). But generally, if you want to project authority and persuade, err on the side of **confidence in wording** – eliminate unnecessary hedges. Women, unfortunately, are often socialized to hedge more (“I’m not sure but…”, “Maybe we could…”) and the book suggests being mindful of that and trimming those verbal tics to level the playing field in meetings. Confidence also comes from **framing things as certain**: e.g., instead of “It might be possible to meet the deadline,” say “We will meet the deadline” (if you have basis to say so – integrity is still important\!). People gravitate towards confident leaders and propositions, as long as that confidence doesn’t cross into unwarranted arrogance.

6. **Language of Concreteness (C):** Concrete language refers to being specific, vivid, and tangible in your words, as opposed to abstract or vague. Berger demonstrates that concrete wording makes messages more **memorable and credible**[\[93\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=It%E2%80%99s%20not%20surprising%20that%20we,the%20message%20and%20the%20messenger)[\[102\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=became%20a%20market%20leader,the%20message%20and%20the%20messenger). Concrete statements paint a clear picture (“Kills bugs dead” or “get your money back”[\[103\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=Similarly%2C%20when%20a%20customer%20service,is%20more%20concrete%20and%20tangible)) whereas abstract ones can seem fuzzy or unproven (“protects your home” or “get a refund” – technically similar meaning but less visceral)[\[93\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=It%E2%80%99s%20not%20surprising%20that%20we,the%20message%20and%20the%20messenger)[\[103\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=Similarly%2C%20when%20a%20customer%20service,is%20more%20concrete%20and%20tangible). In one anecdote, Berger mentions customer service: telling a customer “I’m working to **get you your money back**” versus “I’m working to **issue a refund**” – the former is more concrete (the customer visualizes money back in their pocket) and also feels more empathetic and action-oriented[\[103\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=Similarly%2C%20when%20a%20customer%20service,is%20more%20concrete%20and%20tangible). Concrete language also reduces ambiguity; if you say “Please send this out by 5 PM Tuesday” versus “please send this soon”, you’re more likely to get compliance because the ask is clear and visualizable. Berger also finds an interesting twist: while concrete language is usually better for clarity and convincing most audiences, **abstract language has its place** – particularly when conveying big vision or potential. For instance, startup founders using slightly more abstract language when pitching to investors were seen as more visionary, because abstraction can signal big-picture thinking[\[104\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=,%E2%80%9D). Abstract terms can suggest grand possibilities (e.g., “revolutionizing an industry” vs. “making a faster widget”). So Berger advises to choose based on context: if you need to establish credibility and get people to trust the details, go concrete (especially useful in early or middle stages of influence, or when teaching/training)[\[93\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=It%E2%80%99s%20not%20surprising%20that%20we,the%20message%20and%20the%20messenger). If you need to inspire or indicate long-term strategy, a touch of abstraction can elevate the perception (“paint the forest, not just the trees”). Nevertheless, even visionary messages should have concrete hooks. For everyday influence, leaning concrete is a safe bet: use specific examples, quantify when possible (“over 1 million users” vs. “many users”), and invoke sensory language. Concrete language shows you know your stuff and helps others *see* and *feel* the idea, which drives it home.

By mastering these six types of “magic words,” communicators can **subtly but powerfully alter their persuasiveness**. The beauty is that these are often **small tweaks** – slight rephrasing – that cost nothing but attention to detail, yet yield outsized effects. For example, simply changing a couple of words in an email (“I recommend” instead of “I think we should maybe”) might make the difference between getting action or being ignored[\[41\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=And%20that%E2%80%99s%20where%20we%20get,%E2%80%9D). Or choosing to ask a question rather than make a demand could turn a resistant colleague into a willing collaborator[\[42\]](https://chasejarvis.com/blog/6-types-of-magic-words-that-will-help-you-get-your-way-with-jonah-berger/#:~:text=gets%20promoted%20to%20whether%20songs,who%E2%80%99s%20in%20charge%2C%20who%E2%80%99s%20to).

Berger supports these recommendations with a plethora of studies and real-world observations, making the case that these aren’t just tricks but *science-backed techniques*. He also cautions that context matters: one must use judgment in applying them (e.g., too many questions can annoy, too much confidence without substance can backfire, identity appeals must align with the audience’s values lest they offend[\[98\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=ideas%20and%20a%20vision%2C%20which,you%20can%E2%80%99t%20get%20this%20to)). The book encourages ethical use: these “magic words” should ideally be used to better communicate truth and positive messages, not to deceive.

Some additional gems from *Magic Words*: \- The use of the word “*because*” – classic psychology finding that giving a reason (even a weak one) increases compliance, because people like explanations. So adding “because \[some reason\]” to requests, even if the reason is mild, can help (though Berger would likely say make the reason concrete and identity-relevant for maximum effect). \- Avoiding negations that create the wrong image. For instance, instead of saying “Don’t hesitate to contact me” (which plants the idea of hesitation), say “Feel free to contact me anytime.” The latter is more encouraging and concrete. \- **“You” and “we”** – Berger briefly notes (as seen in a snippet) that brands using “you” in social media get more engagement[\[105\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=Berger%20also%20examines%20the%20power,person) because it directly speaks to the reader, creating a personal dialogue. But in customer support contexts, saying “you” in a certain way (“*If* *you* *can’t get this to work…*”) can sound blaming[\[106\]](https://medium.com/olson-zaltman/a-review-of-jonah-bergers-magic-words-what-to-say-to-get-your-way-02d8c2416193#:~:text=,or%20even%20fault%20on%20the). So, there’s nuance in pronouns: use “you” to empower and connect, not to assign fault.

Overall, *Magic Words* is a modern guide to fine-tuning our language for influence. For executives and engineers, the takeaway is that **small changes in wording can lead to big changes in outcome**. Whether it’s in a product pitch, an email to stakeholders, or a team meeting, being mindful of SPEACC can give you an edge: \- Use **Similarity** to build bridges (mirror key words, adopt the jargon appropriately). \- Pose **Questions** to engage and lead others to your conclusions. \- infuse **Emotion** to make your message resonate and stick. \- frame actions in terms of **Agency and Identity** to motivate and empower. \- speak with **Confidence** by choosing decisive words and avoiding unnecessary hedges. \- increase **Concreteness** to ensure understanding and credibility.

By practicing these techniques, your communication can become more than just information-sharing – it becomes a tool for inspiration and influence. As Berger writes, words are indeed *“powerful psychological tools”* – and the right words, used at the right time, can truly be “magic” in changing minds and behaviors[\[107\]](https://sobrief.com/books/magic-words#:~:text=Magic%20Words%20explores%20the%20power,words%20that%20can%20enhance)[\[108\]](https://5minutebooksummary.com/magic-words-summary/#:~:text=Through%20extensive%20research%20and%20analysis%2C,By%20understanding%20the).
